title: Doubtful Pre-Release Goods: Domestic vs. Imported
vignette: A distributor imports new gadgets from abroad where early release is allowed. At home there is an embargo until the launch date. Should uncertain-status gadgets be treated as embargoed domestically?

options.text: Treat as embargoed within the strict jurisdiction; doubts are resolved towards restriction there.
Permit sale/use; if there's doubt about its origin and it was permissible abroad, the leniency carries over.

title: Knowingly Selling Products Under Initial Use Restriction
vignette: A developer promised that a new application would be free for three years to gather feedback. Can they start selling licenses in the third year to recover costs?

options.text: Forbidden — no commercial benefit may be derived during this initial non-commercial period.
Allowed if sold to users/entities not part of that specific community or not aware of the charter; only signatories are bound by the non-commercial clause.

title: Restricted Asset Straddling Jurisdictional Borders
vignette: Data from new AI models is under a three-year restriction in Country A, but is accessed from Country B where no such rule exists. Should usage in Country B be restricted because of its origin?

options.text: Prohibit — the data's restricted status follows its origin and processing location in Country A.
Permit — the status follows the point of access; usage in Country B is subject to Country B's laws only.

title: Assets with Uncertain Maturity/Restriction Period
vignette: A company buys patents with incomplete records. Some may still be under an agreed initial non-licensing period. Should they assume the patents are restricted until proven otherwise?

options.text: Assume restricted (non-licensable) until proven clear for commercial use. Prioritize compliance.
Assume permitted for licensing unless clear evidence of restriction is found. Prioritize asset utilization.

title: Restricted Items Mixed into a Large Commercial Batch
vignette: One crate of unapproved apples accidentally falls into a shipment of 300 approved crates. Must the whole shipment be recalled or is the small contamination negligible?

options.text: Condemn or recall the entire shipment — no de minimis exceptions for products under such significant restrictions.
Permit sale if the ratio of restricted to approved is extremely low (e.g., 1:200 or less); the restricted items are considered effectively 'nullified' by dilution.

title: Using Waste from Restricted Products for an Unrelated Purpose
vignette: A research lab is testing a new type of tree whose wood is under a 3-year usage restriction (
). Can the lab burn the shells of nuts produced by these trees (which are also under restriction) as fuel for heating the lab, if the shells would otherwise be waste?

options.text: Prohibit any benefit, including heat from burning waste byproducts of the restricted trees.
Permit after burning; the act of complete combustion transforms the material, and the heat is a secondary, indirect benefit from waste. Ashes lose restriction.

title: Using Restricted Plant Material for a Non-Consumptive Product
vignette: A craftsman uses husks from a plant that is under a three-year use restriction (
) to create a natural dye. May a garment dyed with this pigment be sold or used?

options.text: Garment remains restricted — the benefit (color) from the restricted plant material continues in the final product.
Garment permitted — the color is an intangible property, and the original plant material has been transformed. The direct benefit from the
source has ended.

title: Feeding Restricted-Use Agricultural Products to Livestock
vignette: A farmer grows grain that cannot be sold for human food for its first three years. May it be fed to livestock during that period?

options.text: Forbidden — feeding one’s own livestock is considered a personal benefit derived from the restricted product.
Permitted — only direct human consumption or sale for human use is banned; animal feed is a distinct, lower-grade use.

title: Status of Byproducts After Processing Restricted Materials
vignette: Wood from trees under a three-year usage ban is burned to ash. Can the ash be used as fertilizer or is it still restricted?

options.text: Yes; the prohibition ends once the material is fundamentally transformed (e.g., reduced to ash). The ash is a new substance.
No; any residual benefit or use derived from the originally restricted material is still barred. The origin taints the byproduct.

title: Retroactive 'Dilution' of a Restricted Substance Mixture
vignette: Industrial solvent is contaminated with a small amount of a restricted chemical, exceeding the allowed ratio. More solvent is later added to dilute it below the limit. Does this later dilution make the batch usable?

options.text: Yes; the later dilution retroactively meets the acceptable impurity ratio, rendering the batch usable.
No; the mixture became fully restricted the moment the impurity limit was initially exceeded. It cannot be 'un-restricted' by later dilution.
